Data on ''Cementos Argos'']]] The [[Metropolitan Area of Medell√≠n]] contributes 67% of the total GDP of the Department of Antioquia and 11% of the [[economy of Colombia]]. Antioquia is the second-greatest economic region of Colombia. By 2005, Antioquia's GDP was more than US$14,700,000,000 and the top exporting province in Colombia.Revista Semana (2007): "Ruta Empresarial", en Semana, vol. II, Edici√≥n especial, N¬∫ 1329. p. 106. The Aburr√° Valley is the top economy in the province, and its GDP was $7,800 million. Medell√≠n is the second-largest economic region in Colombia, after [[Bogot√°]]. The 2005 Report of the Economic Colombian Review of Proexport and the International Cooperation Agency of Medell√≠n concluded that Medell√≠n was at the same level of GDP contribution to the national economy as cities like [[Panama City]] in Panama, and [[San Jos√© de Costa Rica]]. ===Medell√≠n Cluster=== Medell√≠n created the first Colombian [[business cluster]]. The city is the top exporting region of the country, with 1,750 export businesses based in Medell√≠n. The Cluster was created with the support of the Chamber of Commerce of Medell√≠n and the City Administration for an actual total of 21,000 companies that share 40% of total exports, 25% of the regional GDP, and 40% of Metro Area employment. The main economic activities of the Medell√≠n Cluster (MC) are in [[electricity generation]], textile, fashion design, construction, tourism and business.C√°mara de Comercio de Medell√≠n. [http://www.camaramed.org.co/quees.html Comunidad Clusters] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225183807/http://www.camaramed.org.co/quees.html |date=2012-02-25 }} One current goal of the Medell√≠n Cluster is to include health services, an important sector in the local economy. [[Ruta N]] is a non-profit in Medell√≠n which helps foreign companies set up office in Medell√≠n. ===Unemployment and poverty=== According to data released by the Measuring Monetary Poverty and Inequality Mission (Spanish: ''Misi√≥n para el Empalme de las Series de Empleo, Pobreza y Desigualdad'', MESEP), in November 2009, the poverty rate in Medell√≠n and its metropolitan area was reduced by 22.5%, from 49.7% to 38.5% during the period from 2002 to 2008. Similarly, the poverty rate decreased by 25.2%, from 12.3% to 9.2%. These results are in line with the increased coverage of basic services such as health, education, and public services in the city. In 2014, the poverty rate decreased to 14.7% and extreme poverty to 2.8%.{{cite web|url=http://www.dane.gov.co/files/investigaciones/condiciones_vida/pobreza/bol_pobreza_14_.pdf |title=Data |website=www.dane.gov.co |format=PDF}} The unemployment rate in Medell√≠n and its metropolitan area, as has been the case in Colombia as a whole, has decreased in the past decade. According to data from the National Statistics Department (Spanish: Departamento Administrativo Nacional de Estad√≠stica, DANE) unemployment for Medell√≠n and its Metropolitan Area was reduced by 25%, from 14.1%,{{cite web|url =http://www.dane.gov.co/index.php/mercado-laboral/empleo-y-desempleo|title =DANE - Encuesta Continua de Hogares Total 13 ciudades y √°reas metropolitanas Promedio 12 meses enero - diciembre (2001 - 2006)|date =|access-date =February 1, 2016|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160201162223/https://www.dane.gov.co/index.php/mercado-laboral/empleo-y-desempleo|archivedate =February 1, 2016|df =}} just above the national average of 13.9% in 2005 to 10.6%,{{cite web|url = http://www.dane.gov.co/files/investigaciones/boletines/ech/ech/bol_empleo_dic_15.pdf|title = DANE - Gran Encuesta Integrada de Hogares (GEIH) Enero - Diciembre 2015|date = |access-date = February 1, 2016|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} above the national average of 9.9%, in 2015. However, according to DANE, in 2014 Medell√≠n stood out as one of the most unequal cities of Colombia, with a GINI coefficient of 0.506. ==Urban development== There are signs of heavy urban development within the city of Medell√≠n, particularly with the construction of new skyscrapers. Medell√≠n is currently outpacing all other major Colombian cities, including Bogot√°, in the construction and proposed development of new high-rises. As of October 2016, there were 10 skyscrapers, 410 high-rises, 119 buildings under construction in Medell√≠n, including 48 being planned.{{cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/city/101122/medellin-colombia|title=Medell√≠n|publisher=emporis.com|accessdate=15 November 2016}} Other projects that the city has planned are extensions of the cities metro system to nearby suburbs such as Sabaneta. Currently under construction, the new project is set to open to the public soon. Medell√≠n was awarded 2013 "Innovative City of the Year" by the Wall Street Journal{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/02/medellin-named-innovative-city-of-the-year_n_2794425.html |title=Medellin, Colombia Named ‚ÄòInnovative City Of The Year‚Äô In WSJ And Citi Global Competition |last=Moreno |first=Carolina |website=Huffington Post |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131019220603/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/02/medellin-named-innovative-city-of-the-year_n_2794425.html |archivedate=19 October 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=8 March 2017 |df= }} on March 1 after beating out New York City and [[Tel Aviv]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/ARTICULO-WEB-NEW_NOTA_INTERIOR-12627468.html|title=Medell√≠n, la m√°s innovadora - Archivo Digital de Noticias de Colombia y el Mundo desde 1.990 - eltiempo.com|publisher=|access-date=2013-03-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420231447/http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/ARTICULO-WEB-NEW_NOTA_INTERIOR-12627468.html|archive-date=2013-04-20|dead-url=yes|df=}} ===Comprehensive urban projects=== When [[Sergio Fajardo]] became Mayor of Medell√≠n in 2004, the "Medell√≠n, Commitment of all the Citizens" plan for the city was enacted. One of its fundamental axes was described as "Social Urbanism".{{cite book|last=Fajardo|first=Sergio|title=Medell√≠n, transformaci√≥n de una Ciudad|year=2008|publisher=Alcald√≠a de Medell√≠n|location=Medell√≠n}} The final objective of this model was to promote peace and social equity through its urban policies. To accomplish this, priority was given to the areas of the city where bigger social and economic issues were found. The main tool used with this objective was the planning and development of urban projects that would transform the physical environment while promoting profound social and cultural shifts in the communities they were implemented.{{cite web|last=SCA|title=La transformaci√≥n de Medell√≠n, urbanismo social 2004 - 2007|url=http://socearq.org/index.php/actividades/debates/la-transformacion-de-medellin-urbanismo-social-2004-2007.html|publisher=Sociedad Central de Arquitectos|accessdate=18 May 2013}} The projects were identified and prioritized using six main guidelines as described in the City Plan by the Council of Medell√≠n:{{cite book|last=Alcald√≠a de Medell√≠n|title=Plan de Desarrollo 2004-2007: Medell√≠n, Compromiso de Toda la Ciudadan√≠a|year=2004|publisher=Alcald√≠a de Medell√≠n|location=Medell√≠n}} * The indicators of human development and quality of life will guide the public investment, focusing on first serving the ones in the biggest need. * Public space and infrastructure must become the framework where education and culture are cultivated in places of encounter and coexistence. * Urban projects must simultaneously integrate physical, cultural and social components; improving not only places but also the life and interactions of people in the communities. * The Integrated Metropolitan Transport System must be used as the organizing axis of mobility and projects in the city. All projects have to be directly linked to the main transport system. * The decision to make Medell√≠n an educated city. Education and culture as priorities that guide programs and projects. [[File:Biblioteca Espa√±a(1)-Medellin.JPG|thumb|230px|[[Spain Library (Medell√≠n)|Spain Library]], located in the 1st commune.]] The main objective of these projects is to fight inequity and exclusion. The neighborhoods with the biggest inequity and violence issues are identified and important investments are made in them. There is no previous agenda over what the specific nature of the interventions will finally be since the projects use a communicative approach to define what is best for the community with the active participation of its members. The outcomes will depend on what the neighborhood decides supported by the inclusion of the expertise of city organizations. The projects will have to incorporate all the elements needed to foster development and will be executed simultaneously to assure the biggest impact. Aside from usual city investment in public infrastructure and as a result of this approach to city development, there were four main concrete projects that were established to help achieve the objectives of peace and social equity based on the guidelines proposed in the Medell√≠n City Plan by the Council of Medell√≠n. ===Libraries and "library parks"=== [[File:Biblioteca Leon de Greiff-Exterior4-Medellin.JPG|thumb|left|230px|[[Le√≥n de Greiff Library]]]] {{Main article|Library park (Colombia)}} A "library park" ({{lang-es|Parque biblioteca}}) is a term first used in Medell√≠n for an urban complex formed by a combination of a library building with ample surrounding green space for public use. These library parks are strategically located in the periphery of the city to address the need for more cultural and education space and public services in less affluent neighborhoods.{{cite book|author=Manuela Agudo Catal√°n|title=El romanticismo en Arag√≥n (1838-1854): literatura, prensa y sociedad|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wk2JqkAfwScC&pg=PA94|accessdate=16 August 2013|year=2008|publisher=Universidad de Zaragoza|isbn=978-84-7733-137-7|pages=94‚Äì}} The development of library complexes and schools is part of an effort at cultural transformation.{{cite book|last=Melguizo|first=Jorge|title=La transformaci√≥n de Medell√≠n desde la Cultura|year=2008|publisher=Secretar√≠a de Cultura de Medell√≠n|location=Medell√≠n}} This project also aims to create centralities inside the intervened areas that help consolidate and give a clearer identity to the communities. They are meant to provide a network of activity centers for the promotion of education, culture, sport, and recreation. The initial plan in 2009 built five libraries with attached parks to serve underprivileged neighborhoods. The most famous of this development was possibly the [[Biblioteca Parque Espa√±a]] designed by [[Giancarlo Mazzanti]],.[http://www.americalate.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/col-parquebibliotecaespana-545px.jpg Americalate, fotograf√≠a nocturna del Parque Biblioteca Espa√±a] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018101940/http://www.americalate.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/col-parquebibliotecaespana-545px.jpg |date=2015-10-18 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.americalate.com/2009/09/24/medellin-una-ciudad-que-busca-reposicionarse/|title=americalate.com|publisher=|accessdate=29 November 2016}} and which was named after [[Spain]], who helped fund the construction of one of its buildings. Architects of the other libraries added as part of the program include [[Ricardo La Rotta Caballero]] and [[Hiroshi Naito]]. The four other libraries added were [[Le√≥n de Greiff Library]] (also known as La Ladera Library Park), [[San Javier Library Park]], [[Bethlehem Library Park]], and [[La Quintana Library Park]]. After the initial 2009 program another five libraries were added to the plan for 2011. These libraries are the [[Doce de Octubre Library Park]] for Comunas 5 and 6, Noroccidente; [[Las Estancias Library Park]] for Comunas 8, 9, and Centroriental; [[Parque Biblioteca Guayabal]] for Comuna 15 and Suroccidente; Parque Biblioteca San Crist√≥bal] for Corregimiento and Occidente; and Parque Biblioteca San Antonio de Prado for Corregimiento and Sur.{{cite web |url=http://pbfernandobotero.blogspot.com/p/conoce-el-parque-biblioteca.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130307193109/http://pbfernandobotero.blogspot.com/p/conoce-el-parque-biblioteca.html |archivedate=2013-03-07 |df= }} The idea of "library parks" has served as a model for library spaces in other countries, most notably the [[Manguinhos Library Park]] in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. [[File:Bteca epm.JPG|250px|thumbnail|right|EPM Public Library]] The Medell√≠n Metropolitan Area Library Network is a set of libraries linked together to share resources, efforts, knowledge and experience to improve the educational and cultural conditions of the community. The network consists of over 100 libraries, 29 of which reside in Medell√≠n.{{cite web|title=Libraries|url=http://www.reddebibliotecas.org.co/bibliotecas|website=Library Network|publisher=Red de Bibliotecas|accessdate=13 September 2015}} The Library Network includes all of Medell√≠n's library parks, as well as other regional libraries, such as the Public Pilot Library and the EPM Library. The Library Network was a program created as a metropolitan agreement in 2005 thanks to an alliance of [[Empresas P√∫blicas de Medell√≠n]], its EPM Foundation, the Mayor of Medell√≠n, and the Pilot Public Library. In 2009, the Library Network was awarded the "Access to Learning Award" by the [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]], consisting of one million dollars to the EPM Foundation and the Library Network.{{cite web|title=Colombian Organization Receives ATLA - Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation|url=http://www.gatesfoundation.org/Media-Center/Press-Releases/2009/08/Colombian-Organization-Receives-ATLA|publisher=Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation|accessdate=13 September 2015|date=August 2009}} Additional libraries outside of this network include several other private, public, and university libraries. ===Architecture=== [[File:Punto cero de Medell√≠n.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Point Zero Bridge, decorated with a [[plumb-bob]], symbolizes the center of the city.]] {{Main article|Architecture of Colombia}} Medell√≠n in 2013 won the Veronica Rudge Green Prize in Urban Design, awarded by [[Harvard University]], due to PUI Integral Urban Project Northeast area, designed and implemented by Development Corporation Urbano. Medell√≠n retains very little colonial architecture from the nineteenth century. Although the Aburr√° Valley was a hotspot in agriculture and livestock throughout the colonial period, their relative wealth is not expressed in an outstanding and Cartagena, Tunja, Popay√°n and Bogot√° civil and religious architecture. This can be explained by the fact that the population of Medell√≠n was not political and administrative center and a place geographically isolated whose elite invested little in the development of monumental architecture. From the end of the colony remain, but with many transformations, the Candelaria Church and the Church of the Veracruz. [[File:2018 Medell√≠n fachada de la iglesia de La Veracruz.jpg|thumb|The Church of the Veracruz remain, but with many transformations, from the end of the colony.]] The architecture produced in Colombia between 1850 and 1930 is called "Republican". The use of brick and implementation of European historical styles were the main novelty. Enrique Haeusler designed the Guayaquil Bridge in 1879. But it was the French architect Carlos Carr√© who headlined Republican nineteenth century architecture in Medell√≠n. Carr√© came to town in 1889 and was hired to design and build the new Episcopal Cathedral and several commercial and residential buildings for different parts of the city, especially in the new neighborhood of Guayaquil. The Metropolitan Cathedral was completed in 1931; also are of authorship V√°squez and Carr√© buildings, which are located next to [[Plaza Cisneros]]. The Medell√≠n Antioquia Railway Station was the work of Enrique Olarte, a work that allowed the definitive urban consolidation in Guayaquil sector. In the twenties Republican architecture reached its peak phase. In this period stand the old Municipal Palace (now the Museum of Antioquia) in 1928, the National Palace and the Palace of Departmental Government (now the Palace of Culture) between 1925 and 1928. The latter two works were designed by the Belgian architect [[Agust√≠n Goovaerts]], both inspired by the Belgian modernist, it applied the Romanesque and Gothic styles respectively. Other works of Goovaerts were the Church of the Sacred Heart (sector Guayaquil), the Church of San Ignacio, among others. The thirties highlighted such constructions of the Prado neighborhood as the Egyptian house and the current Teatro Prado. ===Parks=== The main parks of the city include [[Berr√≠o Park]] in the center of the city; [[Bol√≠var Park (Medell√≠n, Colombia)|Bol√≠var Park]], a little further north and framed by the Metropolitan Cathedral; and others in more residential areas like Bethlehem Park, El Poblado Park, and Laureles Park. Several modern parks are interactive and have had a positive reception from the people because they are not only places of recreation but also of education. These include Barefoot Park, Wishes Park, [[Explora Park]], and Bicentennial Park (which was recently opened to mark the bicentenary of Colombia). One of the most visited sites is the [[Arv√≠ Ecotourism Park]], which has an area of about 20,000 hectares, covers virtually the entire territory of the village of [[Santa Elena (Medell√≠n)|Santa Elena]], and runs between the towns of [[Bello, Antioquia|Bello]], [[Copacabana, Antioquia|Copacabana]], and [[Envigado]]. In its trails, lakes, forests and streams, one can practice various sports and activities like trekking, kayaking, biking, camping, fishing, swimming, sailing rowing, horseback riding, bike tours and picnics. Its promontory position over Medell√≠n offers natural landscapes overlooking over the entire city. {{Citation needed|date=April 2012}} The city is surrounded from above by seven hills, which serve as natural viewpoints of the city and are sites for healthy leisure, recreation, enjoyment, research, sport, culture, education and ecotourism. The hills are El Volador, La Asomadera, [[Nutibara Hill|Nutibara]], Pan de Az√∫car, El Salvador, El Picacho and Santo Domingo. In these natural public spaces one can find viewpoints, pre-Hispanic roads, religious icons, culture and Antioquian traditions, bird watching, the most complete herbal living of [[Aburr√° Valley]] and the remains of early settlers native of Medell√≠n, among other attractions. Other parks in the city include North Park and Juan Pablo II Park. The Santa Fe Zoo, founded in 1960, has about 1,000 animals from Asia, Africa, and the Americas. It has a bronze fountain and marble monument, a tribute to the hero of independence Atanasio Girardot. ==Health== [[File:Hospital Pablo Tob√≥n Uribe(4)-Medellin.JPG|200px|thumbnail|right|[[Pablo Tob√≥n Uribe Hospital]] is the top ranked hospital in the city.]] Medell√≠n is considered a top research city in medicine in Colombia, being an exponent of advanced surgical operations in the country and Latin America. Health clinics and dental centers in Medell√≠n have become pioneers in offering high quality services in several medical areas. The University Hospital San Vicente de Paul, the [[Pablo Tobon Uribe Hospital]], and Clinical Cardiovascular Santa Maria have received national and international recognition as pioneers in organ transplantation."Medell√≠n Exporta Salud". ''[[Semana]]''. II, Special Edition (1329). 2007. p. 115. [[Am√©rica Econom√≠a]] magazine ranked Medell√≠n as having eight of the top 100 hospitals and clinics in Latin America. Its highest ranked hospital was Pablo Tobon Uribe Hospital, which ranked in seventh place in 2014.{{cite web|title=Ranking - Hospitals and Clinics|url=http://rankings.americaeconomia.com/mejores-clinicas-hospitales-2014/ranking/|website=Am√©rica Econom√≠a|accessdate=20 February 2015}} The Pablo Tobon Uribe Hospital is non-profit and private. Specialized health centres such as San Vicente Foundation hospitals were recognized with the Silver Category of [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] certification. This is the only hospital outside of the United States of America to obtain this certification.[http://www.metrocuadrado.com/decoracion/content/valioso-patrimonio-arquitectonico-de-colombia-cumple-100-anos San Vicente]: San Vicente Fundaci√≥n, Patrimonio Arquitect√≥nico de Colombia. Among the most recognized universities with notable research work in medicine are the University of Antioquia, CES University,[http://www.udea.edu.co/portal/page/portal/SedesDependencias/SaludPublica UDEA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216065330/http://www.udea.edu.co/portal/page/portal/SedesDependencias/SaludPublica |date=2015-02-16 }}: Facultad Nacional de Salud P√∫blica. and UPB University. ==Education== [[File:UNAL-Bloque M5-Facultad de Minas-Medellin2.JPG|left|thumb|250px|Engineering School, [[National University of Colombia]].]] Medell√≠n is also home to over 30 universities. Among the most important public universities are the following: {{Columns-list|colwidth=30em| * [[University of Antioquia]] * [[National University of Colombia]] * [[Pontifical Bolivarian University]] * [[EAFIT University]] * University of Medell√≠n * University of San Buenaventura * Engineering School of Antioquia * [[Saint Thomas Aquinas University]] * Servicio Nacional de Aprendizaje SENA (Colombia's National Service of Learning SENA) * CES University * Universidad Nacional Abierta y a Distancia * Remington University Corporation * Colegiatura Colombiana{{cite web|url=http://www.colegiatura.edu.co/|publisher=Colegiatura Colombiana|title=Inicio - Colegiatura Colombiana Instituci√≥n Universitaria Medell√≠n}} }} [[File:UPB-Biblioteca Central-Medellin.JPG|thumb|250px|Central Library of [[Pontifical Bolivarian University]].]] There are also important technological centers such as the Metropolitan Institute of Technology (ITM), Jaime Isaza Cadavid's Politecnico, and [[Tecnol√≥gico de Antioquia|Antioquia Institute of Technology]]. During the last decade, the administration of the city has emphasized public education, building schools and libraries in poor quarters. Private schools and colleges have a long tradition in the city, many run by the Catholic Church, private organizations, and foreign institutions. Among them are Gimnasio Internacional de Medell√≠n, The Columbus School (the only SACS-approved school in the city), Theodoro Hertzl School, [[St. Ignatius Loyola College, Medell√≠n|St. Ignatius Loyola College]], Colegio Calasanz, Colegio Colombo Britanico, El Corazonista School, Marymount School, Montemayor Sagrado Corazon, Montessori School, Colegio Font√°n, Gimnasio Los Pinares, Gimnasio Los Alc√°zares, [[San Jose de la Salle]], Instituto Jorge Robledo, the [[Salesian]] Technical School [[Pedro Justo Berr√≠o]], Colegio Cumbres, Colegio San Marcos, Liceo Salazar y Herrera, and 'El Sufragio' [[Salesian]] School. Many non-governmental organizations and official organizations support the development of children and youth from poor communities. [[Ciudad Don Bosco]] cares for [[street children]].[http://www.ciudaddonbosco.org Ciudad Don Bosco Medell√≠n], a center for street children. The pacification of the city brought organizations to the poorest quarters to work with youth involved in urban violence, in order to improve their opportunities. Medell√≠n universities, public and private, also played a role, along with official institutions both local and national. ==Transportation== ===Air transportation=== [[File:2018 aeropuerto internacional Jos√© Mar√≠a C√≥rdova, vista a√©rea.jpg|250px|thumbnail|left|[[Jos√© Mar√≠a C√≥rdova International Airport]]]] Medell√≠n has one domestic airport, [[Olaya Herrera Airport]] (EOH), and one domestic and international airport, [[Jos√© Mar√≠a C√≥rdova Airport]] (MDE), which is located in the city of [[Rionegro]], {{convert|29|km|abbr=off}} east of the city of Medell√≠n. In 2012 the busiest domestic flight route was between Jose Maria Cordova Airport and [[Bogot√°]] while the busiest international route was between Jose Maria Cordova Airport and [[Panama City]]. The [[Jos√© Mar√≠a C√≥rdova International Airport|Jose Maria Cordova Airport]] receives international flights from important carriers such as [[American Airlines]], [[Copa Airlines]], [[JetBlue]] and [[LAN Airlines|Lan Airlines]], which makes the city accessible from the many regions of America. [[Avianca]], the flag air-carrier of Colombia, has also an important activity at this airport. ===Land transportation=== Medell√≠n has two transportation terminals, the North Transportation Terminal and the South Transportation Terminal. The city's public transport system includes diesel buses, taxis, tram and an urban train referred as the [[Medell√≠n Metro]], the only metro system in Colombia. [[File:Metro de Medellin- Linea B sector San Javier.JPG|200px|thumbnail|[[Medell√≠n Metro]] is the only [[metro system]] in Colombia.]] The Metro connects the city with most of its metropolitan area. It has five lines. Line A goes from [[Niqu√≠a station|Niqu√≠a]] to [[La Estrella station|La Estrella]] (north to south), while Line B goes from [[San Antonio station (Medell√≠n)|San Antonio]] to [[San Javier station|San Javier]] (downtown to west). In addition, Line K and Line J, an air cable car, locally known as [[Metrocable (Medell√≠n)|Metrocable]], serve a depressed and geographically difficult area. Line K begins at Acevedo Station on Metro Line A, and continues uphill, ending at Santo Domingo Savio. Line J begins at San Javier Station on Metro Line B, and continues uphill to La Aurora. Line L does not serve communal areas, rather, it is a tourist-oriented line which is connected to [[Arv√≠ Park]] and is part of a social project to bring retreats and nature to the masses.[[Metrocable (Medell√≠n)#cite note-4]] Colombia has become Latin America's largest user of such complementary transportation service throughout the country. [[File:Tunel de Occidente.jpg|thumb|left|Western Tunnel, the longest and most modern tunnel of Latin America.|250px]] In 2006, construction began on Metropl√∫s, a [[bus rapid transit]] service with a dedicated road, much like Bogot√°'s [[TransMilenio]], to allow faster transit for the service's buses. The first line opened two years later than planned in 2011 and a second in 2013.{{cite web|title=Medell√≠n BRT data|url=http://www.brtdata.org/#/location/latin_america/colombia/medellin|publisher=Embarq|accessdate=21 August 2014}} The first leg is the ''Troncal Medell√≠n'', which goes from the Universidad de Medell√≠n in the west to Aranjuez in the northeast part of the city. Metroplus will help lessen the city's pollution and traffic, as many old buses will be taken out of service, while the new buses will work with natural gas.{{cite web|url=http://www.metroplus.gov.co/metroplus/index.php?sub_cat=41&idx=11&ap=8 |title=Metropl√∫s acerc√≥ a los visitantes del #FMB4 con los artistas de la bicicleta | Metropl√∫s |publisher=Metroplus.gov.co |date= |accessdate=2018-06-28}} [[File:Estacion Santo Domingo Savio-Metro de Medellin.JPG|thumb|150px|right|[[Metrocable (Medell√≠n)|Medell√≠n's Metrocable]] at Santo Domingo Savio station.]] Because of its projects on sustainable transport, the city obtained, along with San Francisco, the 2012 Sustainable Transport Award, given by the Institute for Transport and Development Policy.{{cite web|title=Sustainable Transport Award|author=ITDP|url=http://www.itdp.org/get-involved/sustainable-transport-award/previous-award-recipients/medellin-colombia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831112418/http://www.itdp.org/get-involved/sustainable-transport-award/previous-award-recipients/medellin-colombia|archivedate=2013-08-31|df=}} According to EMBARQ Director Holger Dalkmann, "Medell√≠n pioneered the use of cable cars as a transit alternative in low-income informal settlements in hilly areas, moving 3,000 passengers per hour per direction; a real breakthrough now being replicated in Caracas and Rio de Janeiro," [[File:2018 avenida Ayacucho, tranv√≠a de Medell√≠n.jpg|thumb|left|Trams returned in Medellin in 2015 after an absence of 64 years.|250px]] The Colombia and Latin America's largest and most modern tunnel, the Western Tunnel, officially named the Fernando Gomez Martinez Tunnel, is located between Medell√≠n and Santa Fe de Antioquia. It is {{convert|4.6|km|0|abbr=on}} in length and offers security and service technologies for the users. It was inaugurated on January 20, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.caracol.com.co/noticias/actualidad/fue-inaugurado-el-tunel-de-occidente-en-antioquia-el-mas-grande-de-latinoamerica/20060120/nota/240088.aspx|title=Fue inaugurado el T√∫nel de Occidente en Antioquia, el m√°s grande de Latinoam√©rica|trans-title=The West Tunnel was inaugurated in Antioquia, the largest in Latin America|language=es|publisher=caracol.com.co|date=20 January 2006|accessdate=15 November 2016}}{{cite web|title=Tunel de Occidente, Colombia |language=es |url=http://www.tuneldeoccidente.com/ |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921210719/http://www.tuneldeoccidente.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=201%3Afichatecnicareal |archivedate=21 September 2013 |df= }} Originally, [[trams in Medellin]] were the most important transportation until 1950, but, after that, the rapidly increasing population and number of automobiles forcefully closed it in 1951. However, more than 60 years later, a new [[Translohr]] system (rubber-tired "tram"), the [[Ayacucho Tram]], the first modern "tram" in Colombia, was opened on September 30, 2015. It is integrated with the metro system and the local bus network. ====Public transportation statistics==== The average amount of time people spend commuting with public transit in Medell√≠n, for example to and from work, on a weekday is 66 min. 12% of public transit riders, ride for more than 2 hours every day. The average amount of time people wait at a stop or station for public transit is 11 min, while 14.% of riders wait for over 20 minutes on average every day. The average distance people usually ride in a single trip with public transit is 5.9 km, while 5% travel for over 12 km in a single direction.{{cite web|title=Medell√≠n Public Transportation Statistics|publisher= Global Public Transit Index by Moovit|url=https://moovitapp.com/insights/en/Moovit_Insights_Public_Transit_Index_Colombia_Medellin-1642|accessdate=June 19, 2017}} [[File:CC-BY icon.svg|50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License]. ==Demographics== {| class="toccolours" style="float:right; width:210px; float:center; clear:right; margin:1em 0 2em 2em; line-height:140%; font-size:90%;" |- ! colspan=3 style="background:#6688AA"|Growing of the population of

Of the inhabitants of Medell√≠n, 61.3% were born in the city, 38% in other parts of Colombia and 0.3% in another country.{{cite web|url=http://www.dane.gov.co/files/censo2005/perfiles/perfiles.swf|title=Censo General 2005 - Perfiles Departamentales y Municipales|trans-title=General Census 2005 - Departmental and Municipal Profiles|language=es|work=[[National Administrative Department of Statistics (Colombia)|DANE]]|date=2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726041441/http://www.dane.gov.co/files/censo2005/perfiles/perfiles.swf|archivedate=26 July 2008}} According to the [[National Administrative Department of Statistics]], Medell√≠n had, by 2005, a population of 2,223,078 inhabitants, making it the second largest city in Colombia. The metropolitan area of Medell√≠n in 2005 included 3,312,165 inhabitants. There are 5820 people per square kilometer in the city. There were 130,031 people living in the city townships; 46.7% of the population are male and 53.3% are female. Illiteracy is 9.8% in persons older than 5 years old. 98.8% of the households in Medell√≠n have electricity, 97.3% have drinking water, and 91% have a land-line phone. According to the 2005 DANE census, in that year Medell√≠n registered 33,307 births,[http://www.dane.gov.co/index.php?option=com_content&task=category§ionid=16&id=36&Itemid=148 DANE]: Results of births and dead. slightly fewer than in 2004 (33,615). In 2005 the number of deaths was 10,828, in 2004 11,512. ===Ethnicities=== According to figures submitted by the [[National Administrative Department of Statistics|DANE]] census 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.dane.gov.co/files/censo2005/PERFIL_PDF_CG2005/05001T7T000.PDF |title=Data |website=www.dane.gov.co |format=PDF}} the [[ethnographic]] makeup of the city is: * [[Afro-Colombian|Black, mulatto, Afro-Colombian or Afro-descendant]]: 6.5% * [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous Amerindians]]: 0.1% * No ethnic affiliation: 93.4% During the 17th and 18th centuries, Medell√≠n received many immigrants from Spain{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}. Most Indigenous peoples died from the introduction of European diseases, and many of those who survived intermarried with early Spanish settlers, who were mostly men; later, Spanish women also began to immigrate. During the 19th and 20th centuries, immigrants arrived from Lebanon, Jordan, Germany, Italy and Portugal. Many people from Medell√≠n are referred to as [[Paisa Region|Paisas]], people of mainly Spanish ancestry, a lot of them Basque. There is a small Afro-Colombian and Zambo-Colombian (people of Indigenous and African descent) population . The [[Choc√≥ Department]] is just west of Antioquia, and is home to many Afro-Colombian and Zambo-Colombian migrants to Medell√≠n and its vicinity. Migration from the Colombian Caribbean coast has been important, especially that of young people who come to study in Medell√≠n universities and remain to work in the city. The main foreign immigration is of [[Ecuador]]ians in informal trade. ==Culture== [[File:02-063 Palacio de la Cultura Rafael Uribe Uribe.JPG|thumb|200px|left|[[Rafael Uribe Uribe Palace of Culture]]]] The culture in Medell√≠n is strongly linked to a broader Paisa culture (see next section) whose unique attributes famously include their Spanish accent, cuisine, and hospitality. Today, Medell√≠n has several cultural attractions for the public including approximately 40 museums, 21 public parks, 28 theaters, and several public libraries.{{cite web|url=http://medellin.travel/en/where-can-i-go|title=Where can I go?|publisher=Medell√≠n Convention & Visitors Bureau|accessdate=5 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127010605/http://www.medellin.travel/en/where-can-i-go|archivedate=27 January 2012|df=dmy}} The city also contains several [[National Monuments of Colombia]]. [[File:La Raza de Rodrigo Arenas Betancur-Medellin.JPG|thumb|left|200px|''La Raza'' Monument, by [[Rodrigo Arenas|Rodrigo Arenas Betancur]]. It is located in La Alpujarra Administrative Center.]] Most people in Medell√≠n are Catholic, as reflected by Medell√≠n's several churches and religious activities. Among the most representative churches are the [[Metropolitan Cathedral of Medell√≠n|Metropolitan Cathedral]], the largest cathedral in the world built entirely in baked brick. There is also the [[Basilica of Our Lady of Candelaria]], which was the official cathedral until 1931, the [[Church of San Ignacio (Medell√≠n)|Church of San Ignacio]], Baroque on the outside and Colonial on inside, the [[Church of San Jos√© (Medell√≠n)|Church of San Jos√©]], the [[Church of San Antonio (Medell√≠n)|Church of San Antonio]], which has one of the biggest domes in Colombia, the [[Church of San Jos√© del Poblado]], located in the Parque del Poblado where the first European settlement in the [[Aburr√° Valley]] was founded in 1616, and the [[Church of Nuestra Se√±ora de Bel√©n (Medell√≠n)|Church of Nuestra Se√±ora de Bel√©n]]. All of these temples have religious art and are located in the center of the city, which facilitates their journeys. In December, the city is covered with thousands of fairy lights, creating the famous ''[[Christmas lights in Medell√≠n|Alumbrados]]'' (Christmas lights), which are considered by the [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] as one of the ten most beautiful in the world,{{cite web |url = http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/top-10/holiday-lights-photos/#/05-light-displays-colombia_41299_600x450.jpg |title = Top 10 Places to See Holiday Lights|accessdate = 22 December 2011}} and which can be seen mainly on ''La Playa'' Avenue and the Medell√≠n River. [[File:Pano Plazo Botero.jpg|thumb|Plaza Botero, in the background the [[Museum of Antioquia]]|362x362px]] [[Plaza Mayor, Medell√≠n|Plaza Mayor]] is the epicenter of large events and business. By a decree of the municipal government, between 1980 and 1990 all developments or tall buildings necessarily included a sculpture of a famous artist. That is one reason why Medell√≠n has the largest number of sculptures per square kilometer in Colombia.{{Citation needed|date=April 2012}} Furthermore, the city has several festivals and exhibitions year-round. The [[sillero|silletero]] tradition is also closely tied to the region and is considered a part of Colombian [[cultural heritage]]. Since 1957, this tradition has continued in the Silleta Parade that takes place during the annual [[Festival of the Flowers]], where silletas designed with flower arrangements are carried. Works of many prominent artists, both local and foreign, can be seen on the streets of the city. Some artists who stand out are the masters [[Rodrigo Arenas Betancur]] and [[Fernando Botero]]. ===Paisa culture=== {{Main article|Paisa region}} The inhabitants of Medell√≠n are often called ''Antioque√±os'' (people of Antioquia) after their province, rather than ''Medell√≠nenses'' (people of Medell√≠n) after their city. They are also often known as ''[[Paisa Region|Paisas]]'', a name which some suggest comes from the coffee growers. The term ''Paisa'' comes from the word ''paisano'', meaning "fellow countryman". ''Paisas'' make up one of the five different regional cultures within Colombia. In addition to Antioquia, the [[Paisa region]] includes the departments of [[Caldas Department|Caldas]], [[Risaralda Department|Risaralda]], [[Quindio]] and some towns of [[Valle del Cauca]] and [[Department of Tolima|Tolima]]. Although Paisa culture is dominant in Medell√≠n, the so-called "Paisa Capital", the city is becoming more cosmopolitan, now offering music from other regions of Colombia ([[Vallenato]] and [[Department of Choc√≥|Choc√≥]]), and a variety of restaurants including Chinese, Cuban, and Argentinian. The Paisa culture has a Spanish background, and is traditionally Catholic, entrepreneurial, hard-working, and famously hospitable. Paisas are said to speak softly and quickly, to smile easily, and to love music, poetry, soccer, bargaining in the markets, and parties. They are proud of their city, and work hard to keep it clean, stemming from the campaign begun in the 1980s, "Depende tambien de ti, darle amor a Medell√≠n" (It depends on you too to give love to Medell√≠n). The Medell√≠n weekend nightlife, in discos, pubs, parks, and certain dedicated streets, is traditionally called ''rumba''.{{cite web|last=Brown|first=Matthew|url=http://albeiror24.wordpress.com/2008/03/11/colombia-an-emerging-travel-destination/|title=Colombia: An Emerging Travel Destination|accessdate=2008-05-04}} ===Festivals and events=== [[File:Alumbrado 2011 - AV La Playa-2.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Christmas lights in Medell√≠n|Christmas Lighting]] on ''La Playa'' Avenue in 2011.]] * '''[[Festival of the Flowers]]''' is held late July to early August. The Festival, plus many other activities and festivities, is the main axis the [[Desfile de Silleteros]], a colorful and artistic parade of flowers filled saddles on the back for their own grower and already well known internationally. * '''[[Christmas lights in Medell√≠n|Christmas lighting in Medell√≠n]]''' is a traditional seasonal event where the city hangs millions of Christmas lights and holds light shows and other cultural events. National Geographic ranked Medell√≠n Christmas lights display as one of the top 10 places to see Christmas lights in the world. * '''[[International Poetry Festival of Medell√≠n|International Poetry Festival]]''' is an annual congregation of poets, who give at public their poems and readings of a peculiar way mass in parks, auditoriums, neighborhoods and towns near Medell√≠n. This event has been awarded the [[Right Livelihood Award]], the prelude to the Nobel Peace Prize by the Right Livelihood Foundation of Sweden, and its aim is to strive for peace through poetry.{{cite web|url=http://www.rightlivelihood.org/festival.html|title=Festival Internacional de Poes√≠a de Medell√≠n (Colombia)|publisher=Rightlivelihood.org|date=|accessdate=2013-03-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925080401/http://www.rightlivelihood.org/festival.html|archivedate=2013-09-25|df=}} The XVII International Poetry Festival of Medell√≠n was performed between July 14 and 22, 2007, with the participation of over 80 poets from around 55 nations. {{citation needed|date=July 2012}} [[File:Desfile de Silleteros2007-(2)Medellin.JPG|thumb|150px|An example of a ''silleta'' at the [[Festival of the Flowers]].]] * '''[[International Tango Festival (Medell√≠n)|International Tango Festival]]''' is an expression of the tango culture that Medell√≠n adopted as their own. This is a legacy of the bard [[Carlos Gardel]], who died in this city in a plane crash in 1935. Among the activities of the Festival highlights the Tangov√≠a, where people took to the streets en masse to dance, listen to [[tango music|tango]], [[milonga (dance)|milonga]] and obviously having fun at the behest of culture. * '''Book and Culture Festival''' is one of the most important cultural events in Medellin, named itself Festival, rather than Fair, due to its magical atmosphere that revolves around art, books and culture.{{cite web|url=http://www.touringmedellin.com/local_tourism/en/culture/book-and-culture-festival-5 |title=Festival info |website=www.touringmedellin.com}} The Festival is hosted for 10 days at the Botanical Garden in the month of September, and it is held with the participation of both national and international participants and exhibitors from all genres. The Book and Culture Festival is free entry, and aims to promote reading through different workshops. This event is sponsored by the Mayor of Medellin. * '''[[Feria internacional del caballo (Medell√≠n)|Feria internacional del caballo]]''' Since 2009 was added to the horse paisa culture the Feria internacional del caballo, held in October, an exhibition truly unique and beautiful to watch with the participation of several countries and varied and fine horse races.{{cite web|url=http://www.elcolombiano.com/BancoConocimiento/U/una_fiesta_en_torno_al_caballo/una_fiesta_en_torno_al_caballo.asp?CodSeccion=55|title=Una fiesta en torno al caballo|publisher=}} * '''International Jazz Festival''' * '''[[Bullfighting Festival of La Macarena]]''' held every year between January and February. ===Museums and other venues=== Medell√≠n has about 40 galleries, which are one of the main attractions of the city. Some of the main museums include the following: [[File:Museo de Antioquia-Esculturas1-Medellin.JPG|thumb|left|Inside the Museum of Antioquia]] * '''[[Museum of Antioquia]]''' is the most famous museums in Medell√≠n. It was the second museum founded in Colombia and the first in the department of [[Antioquia Department|Antioquia]]. It is located at the heart of the old city hall next to [[Botero Plaza]]. * '''[[Museum of Modern Art of Medell√≠n]]''' (MAMM), founded in 1978, has a valuable collection of contemporary art comprising sculptures, assemblages, paintings, photographs, and prints by local and foreign artists. One of its major attractions is the collection of almost all the works of the Antioquian painter [[D√©bora Arango]]. Another of its main attractions is the projection of cinema-art. It is also headquarters of the International Biennale of Video in September. * '''[[University Museum, University of Antioquia]]''', was created in 1942, is located in University City. The area of [[anthropology]] exhibits a collection of 18 000 pieces of pre-Columbian [[pottery]], [[stone]], [[Mollusc shell|shell]], metal and textiles, the second richest in the country, and a complete ethnographic collection. The area of visual arts includes contemporary painting and sculpture, and includes 1200 pieces of contemporary artists. The area of History at the university collects in a thousand pieces and documents the 200 years of existence of the University, and the natural sciences section displays 5400 pieces, including native and exotic stuffed animals, skins for study, minerals and fossils. [[File:El Castillo-exterior.JPG|thumb|250px|Museum El Castillo]] * '''[[Museum El Castillo]]''', built in 1930 in medieval Gothic and open to the public in 1971, has French-style gardens, explosions room, library and concert hall for 250 people. It has permanent exhibits of porcelain and glass, stained glass, music, sculpture, piano and ballet. * '''[[Interactive Museum EPM]]''' environment is part of [[Parque de los Pies Descalzos]]. Receives 1000 visit a day, mostly students. This is an educational tour of 22 rooms spread over four buildings in which, with technological resources and entertaining way, is explained and interacts with the physical principles of water, energy, gas and telecommunications. It is funded and managed by [[Empresas P√∫blicas de Medell√≠n]]. * '''[[Mineralogy Museum]]''' is located in the School of Mines of the [[National University of Colombia]]. It has a permanent exhibition of a total of 2778 specimens; its collections are recognized by mineralogists and experts among the best museums in South America. * '''[[San Pedro Cemetery Museum]]''' was built in 1842, became a museum in 1998 and declared a [[national monument]] in 1999. This place is an integral part of cultural and architectural heritage of Medell√≠n. Although it falls under the category of sculpture and architecture works representing the funerary art, the space has begun to emerge as a new venue for artistic dissemination. It has preserved collections of local and national art and, on full moon nights, there are concerts, shows, storytelling, theater and dance. Undoubtedly the most significant are the funerary monuments in memory of prominent figures in national history. * '''[[House Museum Master Pedro Nel G√≥mez]]''' was the home of the master [[Pedro Nel G√≥mez]]; it became a museum in 1975 with the donation by the artist and his family of the works in it. It currently has 1500 works, {{convert|200|m2|sqft|lk=out|abbr=off}} of fresco painting and an art library with over 500 volumes. [[File:Tumba de Santa Laura Montoya Upegui.jpg|thumb|170px|Tomb of Saint [[Laura of Saint Catherine of Siena|Laura Montoya Upegui.]]]] [[File:Museo Cementerio San Pedro(1)-Medellin.JPG|thumb|left|[[San Pedro Cemetery Museum]]]] * '''[[Casa Museo Gardeliana]]''' disseminates the culture and history of the [[tango]]. It was declared a Cultural Heritage and Historic Monument by the Council of Medell√≠n in 2002. It was founded on February 14, 1973, by the Argentine Leonardo Nieto Jarbon in the neighborhood Manrique, in a simple, traditional house. The famous tango singer [[Carlos Gardel]] met his death in Medell√≠n in accident airplane crash. There has long existed in the city a deep tango culture. Some plaques testify the visit to the house of personalities from politics, entertainment and literature, as the Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges. * '''[[Parque Explora]]''' is an interactive museum focused on science, technology and many other aspects of knowledge and creativity. It provides, among other attractions, the largest freshwater aquarium in South America that houses fish of the Amazon and Orinoco rivers. * '''[[Planetarium of Medell√≠n]]''' is located in front of the [[Parque de Los Deseos]]. The space includes telescopes and a projection room for 300 people, a dome {{convert|17.5|m|abbr=off}} in diameter, and permanent exhibitions for all ages on Earth and space. Its services include an auditorium, library and a permanent exhibition on space history. Other prominent museums are Centro Cultural Banco de la Rep√∫blica, [[Entomological Museum Francisco Luis Gallego]], Casa Museo Santa Fe, Museum of Natural Sciences, Ethnographic Museum Miguel √Ångel Builes and the [[Laura of Saint Catherine of Siena|Mother Laura Ethnographic Museum]].{{cite web|url= http://www.vatican.va/news_services/liturgy/saints/ns_lit_doc_20040425_montoya_en.html|title= Saint Laura Montoya Upegui |publisher= vatican.va|accessdate=December 6, 2016}} ===Cuisine=== [[File:Bandeja paisa y tazon de frejoles del Chocolos 30062011.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[bandeja paisa]] is the representative food of the city and the department of Antioquia.]] The cuisine of Medell√≠n is again tied to the larger culture of Antioquia. A typical regional dish is the [[bandeja paisa]], meaning the "paisa tray", which usually includes beans, rice, pork, or another meat, [[chorizo]], a fried egg, [[tostones|patac√≥n]]es, salad and avocado. It is traditionally served on a tray slab or wood. It is traditional to consume meals with arepas, which are made with cooked, milled, and mixed corn without further ingredients. For breakfast, it is common to accompany the food with [[hot chocolate]] and possibly a slice of cheese to dunk in the drink. [[Parva (food)|Parva]] is a traditional component of the Antioquian gastronomy as well. This name is given to a wide variety of sweet and savory baked goods, including [[pan de queso]], [[pan de bono]], [[bu√±uelo]]s, and pastries. Other foods that are typical in the region stem from Colombian food industries, such as [[Postob√≥n]] Colombian sodas, the regional [[aguardiente#Colombia|aguardiente]] known as ''Aguardiente Antioque√±o'', and Jet chocolate bars. ==Sports and recreation== Football is the most popular sport and is widely played in the city. Medell√≠n has two professional clubs: [[Atl√©tico Nacional]], founded in 1935, and [[Independiente Medell√≠n]], founded in 1913. Both teams play at the Atanasio Girardot Stadium. The city has a soccer legacy thanks to notable players such as [[Rene Higuita]], [[Iv√°n C√≥rdoba]], [[Andr√©s Escobar]], and [[V√≠ctor Aristiz√°bal]], among many others. Other notable sportsmen of the city are the professional golfer and PGA Tour player [[Camilo Villegas]] and the retired [[Formula One]], [[Champ Car]], and [[IndyCar]] driver [[Roberto Guerrero]]. [[File:Atanacio girardot antes de la apertura de los juegos.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex]]]] A popular sport in Medell√≠n, and generally throughout Antioquia, is [[equitation|horseback riding]]; therefore, it has encouraged trade and production of tools and equipments for this activity, such as chairs and horseshoes for export. During the Festival of the Flowers, the [[cavalcade]]s achieved a [[Guinness World Record]] in 1996 and 1999. The city also has two Colombian professional basketball teams: the [[Arriero]]s of Antioquia and the Mountain Academy. ===Hosting=== The [[Atanasio Girardot Sports Complex]] is the main sports arena complex of the city. It covers an area of {{convert|280000|m¬≤|0|abbr=on}} and encompasses fields and stadiums for practice and competition for 34 sports. This is the headquarters of most professional sports leagues in Medell√≠n. The sports complex has hosted several events, including the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup]], the [[2010 South American Games]], and the [[2001 Copa Am√©rica]]. In 2011, Medell√≠n hosted the 15th IAAF [[Pan American Race Walking Cup]]. Athletes and teams from the countries in North, South, and Central American as well as the Caribbean Islands participated. In 2013, Medell√≠n hosted the IAAF [[Pan American Junior Athletics Championships]] for track and field. Again, athletes and teams from the countries in North, South, and Central America as well as the Caribbean Islands participated. The junior athletes competed as a test trial for the [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics]]. [[Medell√≠n bid for the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics|Medell√≠n bid]] to host the 2018 Summer Youth Olympics but was defeated by [[Buenos Aires]] in the July 4, 2013 vote.{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/news/buenos-aires-elected-as-host-city-for-2018-youth-olympic-games/202222|title=Buenos Aires elected as Host City for 2018 Youth Olympic Games|date=21 July 2016|publisher=}} ===Cycling and BMX=== Another representative sport in the city is [[cycling]]. Its respective sport venue is the Martin Rodriguez Velodrome, named after Colombian [[road racing cyclist]] [[Mart√≠n Emilio Rodr√≠guez]]. [[BMX]] is also popular, and its main venue is the BMX Track Antonio Rold√°n Betancur. The retired cycling three-time [[Tour de France]] stage winner and World Time-Trial Champion [[Santiago Botero|Santiago Botero Echeverry]] and the Olympic Gold Medalist and multiple BMX World Champion [[Mariana Paj√≥n Londo√±o]] are both from Medell√≠n. [[EnCicla]] is the name of Medell√≠n's [[bicycle sharing system]], the first bike sharing program in Latin America and the only one of its kind in Colombia. It was the shared winner of the [[Sustainable Transport Award]] in 2012 along with [[San Francisco]]. EnCicla is the result of an agreement between the metropolitan area of the Valley of Aburr√° and [[EAFIT University]]. EnCicla is integrated within the city's existing infrastructure of cycle routes, mass transit, and public transport systems. It is available from Monday to Friday from 5:30 am to 8 pm from every EnCicla station. {{clear}} ==Symbols== The coat of arms, flag and anthem of the city, has the recognition of official symbols of the municipality of Medell√≠n according to Decree No. 151 of February 20, 2002, and as emblems of the city are part of the corporate image of management municipal, and therefore are present in the acts, events and official media in which these should appear by its representative character. ===Coat of arms=== {{Unreferenced section|date=May 2012}} The Medell√≠n coat of arms is the oldest emblem of the city, has its origins in the granting of its use by King [[Charles II of Spain]] through the [[Real Decreto]] issued in Madrid on March 31 of 1678 whose document says: :"...A blue field coat and in then a very thick and round tower, all around her battlements and a coat of arms which has fifteen parts ‚Äì seven blue and eight gold ‚Äì and on it a crown that touches the tower, on each of the sides a smaller tower, and in between them an image of Our Lady on a cloud with her son in her arms..." {| class="wikitable" style="float:right; font-size:90%; line-height:120%; width:340px; margin:10px" |- !|Heraldic version ! " [[File:Escudo de Medellin Antiguo.svg|thumb|left|upright|First coat of arms of Medell√≠n]] [[File:Escudo de armas de medellin-1678.jpg|upright|thumb|Coat of Arms of Medell√≠n in 1678]] The blazon has remained over time since it was granted, without further changes to the aesthetics, it is noteworthy that there are different stylistic versions between the Mayor and City Council also meets aesthetic not heraldic standards. ===Flag=== To strengthen the links with the region, the municipality adopted the [[flag of the Department of Antioquia]], which was added to the coat of arms of the city, so that these could make difference. The flag consists of two horizontal stripes of equal proportions, the white top and green bottom, and in the middle between two strips is located the coat. The white color symbolizes purity, integrity, obedience, firmness and eloquence. The green represents hope, abundance, freedom and faith. ===Anthem=== The anthem of the city of Medell√≠n is "Anthem of Antioquia", according to Decree No. 151 of February 20, 2002, Article 10, which says: "Anthem of Medell√≠n. '''Mervyn Coleridge Alleyne''' (Trinidad and Tobago, 13 June 1933 - 23 November 2016) was a [[sociolinguist]], [[creolist]] and [[dialectologist]] whose work focused on the [[creole language]]s of the [[Caribbean]].
He attended [[Queen's Royal College]] in [[Port-of-Spain]] and later won a scholarship to the fledgling University College of the West Indies, Mona, [[Jamaica]] which he entered in 1953. After graduating from Mona, Alleyne obtained a PhD from the University of [[Strasbourg]], [[France]]. He returned to the University of the West Indies (UWI), Mona as a lecturer in 1959, and was made Professor of [[Sociolinguistics]] in 1982. He returned to his homeland for a brief spell and lectured at the St Augustine campus of the UWI. He was a Visiting Professor at the [[University of Puerto Rico]], R√≠o Piedras.
Upon retirement from The [[University of the West Indies]], Mona, the title of Professor [[emeritus]] was conferred on him. He was president of the Society for Caribbean Linguistics (SCL) from 1990 to 1992 and was made an honorary member of the SCL in 1998. He also became an honorary member of the [[Linguistic Society of America]] (LSA) in 1996. He is a co-founder of the [[academic journal|journal]] ''Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages''. In 1996, a [[festschrift]] in his honour was published: ''Caribbean Language Issues, Old & New: Papers in Honour of Professor Mervyn Alleyne on the Occasion of His Sixtieth Birthday'' (edited by Pauline Christie, and published by UWI Press). In March 2007, Alleyne was the Humanities Scholar 2007 at The [[University of the West Indies]], [[Cave Hill, Saint Michael, Barbados|Cave Hill]], [[Barbados]]. In October 2011, he was the guest of honour at the special panel discussion ‚ÄúThe Interdisciplinary Scholarship of a Caribbeanist: A Tribute to Dr. Mervyn Alleyne,‚Äù an activity organized at the Institute of Caribbean Studies at the University of Puerto Rico at R√≠o Piedras.
==Significance of his work== Alleyne was best known as a pioneer in [[Creole language|Creole]] Studies. He was one of the few [[Caribbean]]-born participants in the second ever International Conference on Creole Languages held at [[The University of the West Indies]], Mona in April 1968, the proceedings of which were published in 1971 in ''Pidginization and Creolization of Languages'' edited by [[Dell Hymes]]. His paper ‚ÄúAcculturation and the Culture Matrix of Creolization‚Äù elaborated some of the themes which were to characterize his later work. Alleyne disagrees with the idea that creoles necessarily develop from prior pidgins, and he explains the considerable variation among creoles as the result of differing degrees of acculturation among [[Africans]] who came in contact with [[Europe]]ans.
Alleyne repudiated the use of the term 'creole', positing that its meaning is unclear. He carefully avoided it in his book ''Comparative Afro-American'' (1980), arguably the most quoted source on the relevant varieties. In addition to its detailed comparison of structural aspects of [[Sranan]], [[Saramaccan]], [[Jamaican Creole]], [[Guyanese Creole]], among others, this work reveals his preoccupation with the Black experience as a whole, and with the autonomy of [[Culture of Africa|Black culture]]. His fascination with the correlations between the linguistic picture and other aspects of culture, such as religion, manifests itself in ''Roots of Jamaican Culture'' (1988).
==Publications== * ''Acculturation and the cultural matrix of creolization.'' In Pidginization and Creolization of Languages (edited by Dell Hymes), 169‚Äì86. Cambridge (1971): Cambridge University Press. * ''Comparative Afro-American ‚Äî An Historical-Comparative Study of English-Based Afro-American Dialects'', Ann Arbor (1980): Karoma. * ''Theoretical Issues in Caribbean Linguistics'' (editor), Kingston (1982): University of the West Indies, Mona. * ''Studies in Saramaccan Language Structures'' (editor), Amsterdam (1987): University of Amsterdam. * ''Roots of Jamaican Culture'', London (1988): Pluto Press. * ''Syntaxe Historique Cr√©ole'', Paris (1996): Karthala/Presses Universitaires Cr√©oles. * ''The Construction and Representation of Race and Ethnicity in the Caribbean and the World'', Kingston (2002): UWI Press. * ''Folk Medicine of Jamaica'' (with Arvilla Payne-Jackson), Kingston (2004): UWI Press.

{{Infobox ancient site |name = Monastery of the Virgins |alternate_name = |image = |alt = |caption = |map_type = |map_alt = |location = |coordinates = {{coord|31.775808|35.236797|display=inline}} |type = Monastery? |builder = |material = Stone |built = 4th century |abandoned = 614 |cultures = |epochs = [[Byzantine]] |excavations = 1968-1977 |archaeologists = [[Benjamin Mazar]] |condition = ruin, archaeological park |public_access = yes |management = }}
The '''Monastery of the Virgins''' is a structure uncovered during [[Benjamin Mazar]]'s excavations south of [[Jerusalem]]'s [[Temple Mount]]. The large number of Christian religious finds from the site have prompted its identification with a monastery described by a pilgrim, Theodosius the archdeacon, in his ''De Situ Terrae Sanctae'', a work of the early 6th century.<ref name=maps/> The building was constructed in the 4th century on the remains of an earlier [[Herodian]] building identified with the [[Second Temple]] courthouse, and was destroyed during the [[Siege of Jerusalem (614)|Persian sack of Jerusalem]] in 614.
==Excavations== [[File:Temple Mount southern wall 200509.jpg|thumb|The southern Wall of the Temple Mount. The Monastery of the Virgins lies beyond steps leading up to the Triple Huldah Gate]] The building identified as the Monastery of the Virgins was unearthed in Area XV<ref name=xv/> of Mazar's excavations of the [[Ophel]] on behalf of the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]. Carried out between 1968 and 1977, the excavations revealed that a crowded residential neighbourhood stood in the area to the immediate south of the Temple Mount enclosure during Jerusalem's [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine Period]].<ref name=byzantine/> {{convert|10|m|ft}} from the [[Huldah Gates|Triple Huldah Gate]], at the foot of the Temple Mount's [[southern wall]], the excavators revealed a structure whose plan resembled a typical Byzantine courtyard house, with wings arranged around a central courtyard. Built on top in the remains of a large [[Jerusalem during the Second Temple Period|Second Temple Period]] building and an older burial cave, the house featured three stories of which the basement and ground floor were well preserved.<ref name=xv/><ref name=guide/> The excavation of the building yielded earlier [[History of ancient Israel and Judah#Iron Age II|Iron Age II]] shards, including a [[LMLK seal]] and the head of a fertility figurine. However, as a result of the building's excellent state of preservation digging beneath its floors was abandoned in order to allow its display to the public.<ref name=xv/>
Measuring {{convert|17.9|m|ft}} by {{convert|17.3|m|ft}}, the structure was built in the early 4th century as a single spacious unit.<ref name=guide/> Its ground floor included the courtyard, a kitchen, shops and staircases leading to the basement and the floor above, which housed a chapel.<ref name=review/> In the mid-6th century the northern and southern wings of its ground floor were modified and sealed off from the rest of the building.<ref name=guide/>
A destruction layer testifies to the destruction of the building in a great conflagration, probably during the Persian sack of the city in 614.<ref name=intro/> In the destruction layer were found the remnants of the upper floor, which collapsed into the floor below.<ref name=bar/> The remains of weapons, probably the defenders', were also found at the site. These include a sword, a scabbard, a pickaxe, a dagger and an [[Shield boss|umbo]], a rare feature of the Byzantine weapons repertoire.<ref name=arms/>
While adjacent areas were built over during the subsequent Islamic periods, the building in area XV was left undisturbed. This allowed for its excellent state of preservation. It is currently accessible to visitors to the Jerusalem Archaeological Park at the foot of the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]].<ref name=bar/>
===Finds=== Multiple items of ecclesiastical nature were found in the structure. These include fragments of marble [[Iconostasis|chancel screens]], an [[altar table]] and a Second-Temple era stone [[ossuary]] in use as a [[reliquary]] and containing a skull.<ref name=guide/> Crosses were ubiquitous, including on roof tiles, oil lamps, door knockers, and several bronze crosses, one of which was {{convert|65|cm|inch}} in length.<ref name=bar/> Several fragments of a chancel screen depict two deer, Christian symbols of faith and devotion mentioned in {{bibleverse||Psalms|42:2|HE}}, facing a cross planted on the Hill of [[Golgotha]]. A stone lintel was found depicting a cross enclosed within a wreath.<ref name=bar/>
Additional finds include copper alloy chains and incense bowls,<ref>[[#Mazar1999|Mazar 1999, pp. 17]]</ref> copper alloy lock and clasps decorated with the image of an arched entrance to a church,<ref>[[#Mazar1999|Mazar 1999, pp. 15]]</ref> a sinuous dragon-headed arm from a multi-armed copper candelabra, and a copper hearth with decorative animal legs complete with rings for suspension.<ref>[[#Mazar1999|Mazar 1999, pp. 41-42]]</ref>
In the northern section of the building which included the kitchen and several storage rooms, were found multiple storage jars. In some of these were found remnants of the food they once contained, including [[lentil]] and [[chickpea]].<ref>[[#Mazar1999|Mazar 1999, pp. 37]]</ref>
==Identification==
===Monastery of the Virgins===
The large number of Christian items found in the structure have led to its identification with a monastery described by Theodosius the archdeacon in his ''De Situ Terrae Sanctae'' (On the Topography of the Holy Land). Theodosius describes a monastery of nuns at the foot of the Temple Mount's southeastern corner:<ref name=maps/><ref name=guide/> {{quote|Down below the pinnacle of the Temple is a monastery of virgins, and whenever one of them passes from this life, she is buried there inside the monastery. All their lives they never go out of the door by which they entered this place. The door is opened only for a nun or a penitent who wishes to join the monastery, but otherwise the virgins are always shut in. Their food is let down to them from the walls, but they have their water there in cisterns.<ref name=pilgrims/>}}
The excavators believe that the monastery had initially occupied the entire structure. In the 5th century, however, Jerusalem was granted [[Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem|patriarchal status]] and the following century saw the city develop and expand. As population density in Jerusalem grew, the needs of numerous pilgrims to the holy city led to a reduction in the Monastery's area in favour of public facilities. In the mid 6th century, two wings were detached from the monastery and sealed off, the northern wing to act as a public kitchen and the southern converted into a row of shops.<ref name=guide/><ref name=intro/> Food for the monastery was prepared in the public kitchen and delivered through two windows left open between the two sections of the building.<ref name=xv/>
Adjacent buildings have aided the identification of the building as a monastery. {{convert|6|ft|m}} from the Temple Mount wall, behind the monastery, stood a vaulted chamber with a sloping floor. This has been identified as a collection vat for wine, above which once stood a winery, a common feature of Byzantine monasteries. A two story structure to the east of the Monastery may have served as a [[hospice]]. Thirty well-preserved rooms were found on its ground floor, as was a red cross painted on a lintel in the building, and large watering pool on the outside.<ref name=bar/>
While the building certainly was a monastery, certain finds nevertheless cast doubt on its identification with Theodosius' Monastery of the Virgins. Theodosius's description dates from the early 6th century, while the structural modifications isolating the central portion have only been dated to the mid 6th century, and possibly later. Furthermore, Greek inscriptions found in the building feature no women, only men, including one reading "for the offering and salvation of the Timotheus the priest".<ref name=review/>
The identification of the site with Theodosius' monastery was first proposed by [[Yizhar Hirschfeld]]. [[Yoram Tsafrir]] has suggested that the monastery may have been located on the slopes below of the Temple Mount which have not yet been excavated or even in the hollows of the Temple Mount itself, within [[Solomon's Stables]]. No evidence has been found to corroborate either suggestions.<ref name=xv/>
===Second Temple Courthouse=== Underneath the coarse stones of the Byzantine walls, the walls of the monastery were built of large finely dressed stones, plastered and molded at the joints, a feature of [[Herodian]] construction. The monastery had been built over the remains of a large Second-Temple-era building which had stood adjacent to a major entrance to the Herodian Temple Mount. Benjamin Mazar had suggested that this may have been a courthouse of the [[Sanhedrin]], the supreme Jewish judicial and legislative body, a building referred to in the [[Mishnah]], ''[[Tractate Sanhedrin]]'' 11.2. Additional support for this identification comes from a fragment of a Hebrew inscription found nearby. The inscription contained the word ''[z]kenim'' (''elders''), probably referring to the Sanhedrin.<ref name=bar/>
==Publication== Although completed in 1977, the results of the Temple Mount excavations had not been published by Benjamin Mazar's death in 1995. In 1996 the Institute of Archaeology of the Hebrew University authorized his granddaughter, [[Eilat Mazar]], to publish the finds. Eilat Mazar had been her grandfather's research assistant, an area supervisor in the nearby [[City of David]] excavations, and had directed her own excavation in the Ophel in 1986-1987. The excavation report for area XV and the Monastery of the Virgins was finally published in 2003.<ref name=review/><ref name=bar/>

5th edition: [[Plume (publisher)|Plume]] | media_type = paperback book | pages = | isbn = 978-0452289185 | oclc = }} '''''Mystery Train: Images of America in Rock 'N' Roll Music''''' is a [[non-fiction]] book written in 1975 by [[Greil Marcus]]. It features critical essays centered around artists such as [[Elvis Presley]], [[Sly Stone]], [[Robert Johnson]], and [[Randy Newman]]. ==Authorship== [[Greil Marcus]], rock critic and columnist for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', and contributor to other publications, such as ''[[Creem]]'', the ''[[The Village Voice|Village Voice]]'', and ''[[Artforum]]'', wrote ''Mystery Train'' in 1975. In the prologue, he relates that the book "is no attempt at synthesis, but a recognition of unities in the American imagination that already exist."Marcus (1975) The writing, according to the author, took about "two years of doing nothing else."Sheffield (2015) ''Mystery Train'', according to one reviewer, reflects on what could be called "the historical turn" that rock took at the close of the [[1960s in music|60s]], initiated by [[Bob Dylan]] and [[the Band]], and followed through by everyone from [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] to [[Randy Newman]], the music moving "beyond rock'n'roll's teenage immersion in the present to an adult sophistication steeped in deep knowledge of rock's roots in blues and country and lyrics that likewise looked to the past for inspiration."Reynolds (2012) According to another reviewer, Marcus proceeds in his examination of American popular culture with the "democratic assumption" that Presley and [[Herman Melville]] are already cultural and political equals, and are, therefore, "in conversation with one another - having a dialogue about freedom and limits, innovation and tradition, American dreams and American obsessions."Cantwell (2015) When the 2nd edition came out, Elvis had recently died, and Marcus was asked to amend the chapter relating to Elvis by putting everything in the [[past tense]] but he refused, because, he said, "Elvis' presence was so powerful, I felt he's always in the [[present tense]]."Sheffield (2015) ''Mystery Train'' opens with an episode on the ''[[Dick Cavett show]]'', where [[Little Richard]] interrupts a disagreement between a writer and a critic, and closes with a [[Transcription (linguistics)|transcript]] of [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] arguing with producer [[Sam Phillips]] as they are setting up to record "[[Great Balls of Fire]]" in 1957.Marcus (1975). ==Critical reception== [[Frank Rich]] reviewed the book for ''[[The Village Voice]]'' and wrote that Marcus' "frame of reference is so vast that he never runs out of connections worth making between the music he loves and just about anything else that matters in American art and life.‚Äù [[David Itzkoff]] and [[Alan Light]], in a 2005 critical roundup of music-related books, claimed that ''Myster Train'' is "perhaps the finest book ever written about pop music."Itzkoff, Light (2005) ''[[New York Times]]'' literary critic [[Dwight Garner (critic)|Dwight Garner]] stated in 2015 that "most critics and serious listeners think [''Mystery Train'']‚Äôs almost certainly the best book yet written about American music in general, and about rock in particular."Garner (2015) In 2011, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine picked it among the "100 best and most influential [books] written in English since 1923."''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' (2011) ==List of contents== *Author's note *PROLOGUE *ANCESTORS :*[[Harmonica Frank|HARMONICA FRANK]] :*[[Robert Johnson|ROBERT JOHNSON]] *INHERITORS :*[[The Band|THE BAND]]: Pilgrims' Progress ::''Crossing the Border / Stranger Blues / The Righteous Land / Even Stranger Blues / The Weight'' :*[[Sly Stone|SLY STONE]]: The Myth of Staggerlee ::''Staggerlee / Sly Stone / Riot / Sly Versus Superfly / A Quiet Rebellion'' :*[[Randy Newman|RANDY NEWMAN]]: Every Man Is Free ::''Pop / Newman's America, 1 / Newman's America, 2 / Newman's Failure'' :*[[Elvis Presley|ELVIS]]: Presliad ::''Fanfare / Hillbilly Music / Raised Up / The Rockabilly Moment / Elvis Moves Out / The Boy Who Stole The Blues / The Pink Cadillac / Elvis At Home / Mystery Train / Finale'' *EPILOGUE *NOTES AND music|1970s]]. *''[[Invisible Republic]]'' (1997), on the creation and cultural importance of ''[[The Basement Tapes]]'', a series of recordings made by [[Bob Dylan]] in 1967 in collaboration with the
