{{redirect2|NSA wiretapping|NSA warrantless surveillance|the related controversy about data-mining of domestic call records|MAINWAY|the programs leaked in 2013|Global surveillance disclosures (2013‚Äìpresent)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} [[File:National Security Agency.svg|right|thumb|180px|[[National Security Agency]] logo]] {{NSA surveillance|1}} '''NSA warrantless surveillance''' (also commonly referred to as "'''warrantless-wiretapping'''" or "'''-wiretaps'''") refers to the [[surveillance]] of persons within the United States, including United States citizens, during the collection of notionally [[foreign intelligence]] by the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) as part of the [[Terrorist Surveillance Program]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/23/politics/23cnd-wiretap.html |work=The New York Times |title=White House Begins New Effort to Defend Surveillance Program |first1=David E. |last1=Sanger |first2=John |last2=O'Neil |date=January 23, 2006}}</ref> The NSA was authorized to monitor, without obtaining a [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act|FISA warrant]], the [[telephone call|phone calls]], Internet activity, text messages and other communication involving any party believed by the NSA to be outside the U.S., even if the other end of the communication lay within the U.S.
Critics claimed that the program was an effort to silence critics of the Administration and its handling of several controversial issues. Under public pressure, the Administration allegedly ended the program in January 2007 and resumed seeking warrants from the [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court|Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]] (FISC).<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news|url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/politics/20060117gonzales_Letter.pdf|title=Gonzales_Letter |work=The New York Times}}</ref> In 2008 [[United States Congress|Congress]] passed the [[Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 Amendments Act of 2008|FISA Amendments Act of 2008]], which relaxed some of the original FISC requirements.
During the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Barack Obama Administration]], the NSA allegedly continued surveilling without warrants despite campaign promises to end the practice.<ref>{{ cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/01/us/01nsa.html |first1=Charlie |last1=Savage |first2=James |last2=Risen |date=March 31, 2010 |work=The New York Times |title=Federal Judge Finds N.S.A. Wiretaps Were Illegal}}</ref> In April 2009 officials at the [[United States Department of Justice]] acknowledged that the NSA had engaged in "overcollection" of domestic communications in excess of the FISC's authority, but claimed that the acts were unintentional and had since been rectified.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/16/us/16nsa.html |title=Officials Say U.S. Wiretaps Exceeded Law |author=[[Eric Lichtblau]] and [[James Risen]] |work=The New York Times |date=April 15, 2009 |accessdate=September 5, 2012}}</ref> {{toclimit|3}}
== History == A week after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|9/11 attacks]], Congress passed the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists]] (AUMF), which inaugurated the "[[War on Terror]]". It later featured heavily in arguments over the NSA program.
Soon after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks|9/11 attacks]] President Bush established the [[President's Surveillance Program]]. As part of the program, the [[Terrorist Surveillance Program]] was established pursuant to an [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]] that authorized the NSA to surveil certain telephone calls without obtaining a warrant (see {{UnitedStatesCode|50|1802}} {{UnitedStatesCode|50|1809}}). The complete details of the executive order are not public, but according to administration statements,<ref name="Justice.gov-AttyGeneral">{{cite press release|title=Prepared Statement of Hon. Alberto R. Gonzales, Attorney General of the United States|date=February 6, 2006|publisher=US Department of Justice|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/archive/ag/speeches/2006/ag_speech_060206.html}}</ref> the authorization covers communication originating overseas from or to a person suspected of having links to terrorist organizations or their affiliates even when the other party to the call is within the US.
In October 2001, Congress passed the [[Patriot Act]], which granted the administration broad powers to fight terrorism. The Bush administration used these powers to bypass the FISC and directed the NSA to spy directly on [[al-Qaeda]] via a new [[NSA electronic surveillance program]]. Reports at the time indicate that an "apparently accidental" "glitch" resulted in the interception of communications that were between two U.S. parties.<ref name="nytimes051221">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/21/politics/21nsa.html|title=Spying Program Snared U.S. Calls|work=The New York Times|author1=James Risen |author2=Eric Lichtblau |lastauthoramp=yes |date=December 21, 2005|accessdate=May 28, 2006}}</ref> This act was challenged by multiple groups, including [[United States Congress|Congress]], as unconstitutional.
The precise scope of the program remains secret, but the NSA was provided total, unsupervised access to all fiber-optic communications between the nation's largest telecommunication companies' major interconnected locations, encompassing phone conversations, email, Internet activity, text messages and corporate private network traffic.<ref>{{cite web |title=AT&T‚Äôs Role in Dragnet Surveillance of Millions of Its Customers |work=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]] |url=https://www.eff.org/files/filenode/att/presskit/ATT_onepager.pdf }}</ref>
FISA makes it illegal to intentionally engage in [[Surveillance|electronic surveillance]] as an official act or to disclose or use information obtained by such surveillance under as an official act, knowing that it was not authorized by statute; this is punishable with a fine of up to $10,000, up to five years in prison or both.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/50/1809 |title=US CODE: Title 50, section 1809. Criminal sanctions}}</ref> The [[Wiretap Act]] prohibits any person from illegally intercepting, disclosing, using or divulging phone calls or electronic communications; this is punishable with a fine, up to five years in prison, or both.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/2511 |title=US CODE: Title 18, section 2511. Interception and disclosure of wire, oral, or electronic communications prohibited}}</ref>
After an article about the program, (which had been code-named [[Stellar Wind (code name)|Stellar Wind]]), was published in ''[[The New York Times]]'' on December 16, 2005, Attorney General [[Alberto Gonzales]] confirmed its existence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/16/politics/16program.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=December 29, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 16, 2005|author1=James Risen |author2=Eric Lichtblau |lastauthoramp=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts |work=NYT's Risen & Lichtblau's December 16, 2005 Bush Lets U.S. Spy on Callers Without Courts |url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines05/1216-01.htm |accessdate=February 18, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206162614/http://www.commondreams.org/headlines05/1216-01.htm |archivedate=February 6, 2006 |df=mdy }} via commondreams.org</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/13/opinion/13pubed.html |work=The New York Times |title=Eavesdropping and the Election: An Answer on the Question of Timing |first=Byron |last=Calame |date=August 13, 2006 |accessdate=May 20, 2010}}</ref> The ''Times'' had published the story after learning that the Bush administration was considering seeking a court injunction to block publication.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2008/03/the_education_of_a_911_reporter.html |title=The Education of a 9/11 Reporter: The inside drama behind the Times' warrantless wiretapping story.|last=Lichtblau|first=Eric|work=Slate|date=March 26, 2008|accessdate=March 31, 2008}}</ref> [[Bill Keller]], the newspaper's executive editor, had withheld the story from publication since before the [[2004 Presidential Election (United States)|2004 Presidential Election]]. The published story was essentially the same that reporters [[James Risen]] and [[Eric Lichtblau]] had submitted in 2004. The delay drew criticism, claiming that an earlier publication could have changed the election's outcome.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.salon.com/2006/08/14/times_24/ |title=What the Times knew, and when it knew it |last=Grieve |first=Tim |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |date=August 14, 2006 |accessdate=June 22, 2008}}</ref> In a December 2008 interview, former Justice Department employee [[Thomas Tamm]] claimed to be the initial whistle-blower.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/whistleblower-who-exposed-warrantless-wiretaps-82805 |title=The Fed Who Blew the Whistle |last=Isikoff |first=Michael |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=December 13, 2008 |accessdate=December 13, 2008}}</ref> The FBI began investigating leaks about the program in 2005, assigning 25 agents and 5 prosecutors.<ref name=shane2010 />
Attorney and author [[Glenn Greenwald]] argued:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://glenngreenwald.blogspot.com/2006/02/nsa-legal-arguments.html|title=NSA legal arguments|last=Greenwald|first=Glenn|date=February 19, 2006|publisher=Glenngreenwald.blogspot.com|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref>{{quote|Congress passed a law in 1978 making it a ''criminal offense'' to eavesdrop on Americans without judicial oversight. Nobody of any significance ever claimed that that law was unconstitutional. The Administration not only never claimed it was unconstitutional, but Bush expressly asked for changes to the law in the aftermath of 9/11, thereafter praised the law, and misled Congress and the American people into believing that they were complying with the law. In reality, the Administration was secretly breaking the law, and then pleaded with ''The New York Times'' not to reveal this. Once caught, the Administration claimed it has the right to break the law and will continue to do so.|sign=|source=}}Gonzales said the program authorized warrantless intercepts where the government had "a reasonable basis to conclude that one party to the communication is a member of al Qaeda, affiliated with al Qaeda, or a member of an organization affiliated with [[al Qaeda]], or working in support of al Qaeda" and that one party to the conversation was "outside of the United States".<ref name="WHbrief121905">{{cite press release |publisher=The White House |date=December 19, 2005 |title=Press Briefing by Attorney General Alberto Gonzales and General Michael Hayden, Principal Deputy Director for National Intelligence |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2005/12/print/20051219-1.html}}</ref> The revelation raised immediate concern among elected officials, civil right activists, legal scholars and the public at large about the legality and constitutionality of the program and its potential for abuse. The controversy expanded to include the press' role in exposing a [[classified information|classified]] program, the role and responsibility of Congress executive oversight and the scope and extent of presidential powers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cruxlux.com/debate/50/the-warrantless-wiretapping-of-americans-by-the-bush-adminis |title=Debate on warrantless wiretapping legality |accessdate=January 23, 2007 |archivedate=January 29, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129235544/http://www.cruxlux.com/debate/50/the-warrantless-wiretapping-of-americans-by-the-bush-adminis }}</ref>
CRS released a report on the NSA program, "Presidential Authority to Conduct Warrantless Electronic Surveillance to Gather Foreign Intelligence Information", on January 5, 2006 that concluded:
{{quote|While courts have generally accepted that the President has the power to conduct domestic electronic surveillance within the United States inside the constraints of the Fourth Amendment, no court has held squarely that the Constitution disables the Congress from endeavoring to set limits on that power. To the contrary, the Supreme Court has stated that Congress does indeed have power to regulate domestic surveillance, and has not ruled on the extent to which Congress can act with respect to electronic surveillance to collect foreign intelligence information.<ref name="FAS.org-m010506" /><ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Eggen |pages=A05 |title=Congressional Agency Questions Legality of Wiretaps |date=January 19, 2006 |work=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/01/18/AR2006011802158.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Elizabeth |last=Holtzman |title=The Impeachment of George W. Bush |date=January 11, 2006 |work=The Nation |url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20060130/holtzman}}</ref>|sign=|source=}}
On January 18, 2006 the [[Congressional Research Service]] released another report, "Statutory Procedures Under Which Congress Is To Be Informed of U.S. Intelligence Activities, Including Covert Actions".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.findlaw.com/hdocs/docs/nsa/crs11806rpt.pdf|title=FindLaw|work=Statutory Procedures Under Which Congress Is To Be Informed of U.S. Intelligence Activities, Including Covert Actions|format=PDF|accessdate=January 1, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/intel/m011806.pdf|title=Statutory Procedures Under Which Congress Is To Be Informed of U.S. Intelligence Activities, Including Covert Actions|last=Cumming|first=Alfred|date=January 18, 2006|publisher=Federation of American Scientists|format=PDF}}</ref> That report found that "[b]ased upon publicly reported descriptions of the program, the NSA surveillance program would appear to fall more closely under the definition of an intelligence collection program, rather than qualify as a covert action program as defined by statute", and, therefore, found no specific statutory basis for limiting briefings on the terrorist surveillance program.<ref>"If the NSA surveillance program were to consider an intelligence collection program, limiting congressional notification of the NSA program to the Gang of Eight, which some Members who were briefed about the program contend, would appear to be inconsistent with the law, which requires that the 'congressional intelligence committees be kept fully and currently informed of all intelligence activities', other than those involving covert actions." ‚Äì excerpted from the Congressional Research Service publication, "Statutory Procedures Under Which Congress Is To Be Informed of U.S. Intelligence Activities, Including Covert Actions"</ref> However, the report goes on to note in its concluding paragraph that limited disclosure is also permitted under the statute "in order to protect intelligence sources and methods".<ref>"The executive branch may assert that the mere discussion of the NSA program generally could expose certain intelligence sources and methods to disclosure, thus making it necessary to limit the number of those knowledgeable of the program in order to reduce the risk of such disclosure occurring." ‚Äì excerpted from the Congressional Research Service publication, "Statutory Procedures Under Which Congress Is To Be Informed of U.S. Intelligence Activities, Including Covert Actions"</ref>
=== Legal action === While not directly ruling on the legality of domestic surveillance, the Supreme Court can be seen as having come down on both sides of the Constitution/statute question, in somewhat analogous circumstances.
In ''[[Hamdi v. Rumsfeld]]'' (2004) the government claimed that AUMF authorized the detention of U.S. citizens designated as an [[enemy combatant]] despite its lack of specific language to that effect and notwithstanding the provisions of {{UnitedStatesCode|source=f|18|4001}}(a) that forbids the government to detain an American citizen except by act of Congress. In that case, the Court ruled:
{{quote|[B]ecause we conclude that the Government's second assertion ["that ¬ß 4001(a) is satisfied, because Hamdi is being detained "pursuant to an Act of Congress" [the AUMF]] is correct, we do not address the first. In other words, for the reasons that follow, we conclude that the AUMF is explicit congressional authorization for the detention of individuals ... and that the AUMF satisfied ¬ß 4001(a)'s requirement that a detention be "pursuant to an Act of Congress".}}
However, in ''[[Hamdan v. Rumsfeld]]'' the Court rejected the government's argument that AUMF implicitly authorized the President to establish [[Military justice|military commissions]] in violation of the [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]]. The Court held:
{{quote|Neither of these congressional Acts, [AUMF or ATC] however, expands the President's authority to convene military commissions. First, while we assume that the AUMF activated the President's war powers, see ''Hamdi v. Rumsfeld'', {{Ussc|source=f|542|507|2004}}) (plurality opinion), and that those powers include the authority to convene military commissions in appropriate circumstances, see ''id.'', at 518; ''Quirin'', 317 U. S., at 28‚Äì29; see also ''Yamashita'', 327 U. S., at 11, there is nothing in the text or legislative history of the AUMF even hinting that Congress intended to expand or alter the authorization set forth in Article 21 of the [[Uniform Code of Military Justice|UCMJ]]. Cf. Yerger, 8 Wall., at 105 ("Repeals by implication are not favored")}}
In footnote 23, the Court rejected the notion that Congress is impotent to regulate the exercise of executive war powers:
{{quote|Whether or not the President has independent power, absent congressional authorization, to convene military commissions, he may not disregard limitations that Congress has, in proper exercise of its own war powers, placed on his powers. See ''Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer'', 343 U. S. 579, 637 (1952) (Jackson, J., concurring). The Government does not argue otherwise.}}
Dozens of civil suits against the government and telecommunications companies over the program were consolidated before the chief judge of the Northern District of California, [[Vaughn R. Walker]]. One of the cases was a [[Class action|class-action]] lawsuit against [[AT&T]], focusing on allegations that the company had provided the NSA with its customers' phone and Internet communications for a data-mining operation. Plaintiffs in a second case were the [[al-Haramain Foundation]] and two of its lawyers.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam|last=Liptak|title=U.S. Defends Surveillance to 3 Skeptical Judges |date=August 16, 2007 |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/16/washington/16nsa.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Bob|last=Egelko|title=Classified evidence debated: Court likely to allow suit against AT&T, reject wiretap case |date=August 16, 2007 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2007/08/16/BAPCRJEFN.DTL&type=printable}}</ref>
On August 17, 2006, Judge [[Anna Diggs Taylor]] of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan]] ruled in ''[[ACLU v. NSA]]'' that the [[Terrorist Surveillance Program]] was unconstitutional under the Fourth and First Amendments and enjoined the NSA from using the program to conduct electronic surveillance "in contravention of [FISA or Title III]".<ref name="Wired.com-Judge-NSA" /> She wrote:<ref>[http://www.mied.uscourts.gov/eGov/taylorpdf/06%2010204.pdf Ruling] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820121827/http://www.mied.uscourts.gov/eGov/taylorpdf/06%2010204.pdf|date=August 20, 2006}} The quote is from page 33.</ref>
{{quote|The President of the United States, a creature of the same Constitution which gave us these Amendments, has indisputably violated the Fourth in failing to procure judicial orders as required by FISA, and accordingly has violated the First Amendment Rights of these Plaintiffs as well.}}
In August 2007, a three-judge panel of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] heard arguments in two lawsuits challenging the program. On November 16, 2007, the three judges‚Äî[[M. Margaret McKeown]], [[Michael Daly Hawkins]] and [[Harry Pregerson]]‚Äîissued a 27-page ruling that the al-Haramain Foundation could not introduce a key piece of evidence because it fell under the government's claim of [[State Secrets Privilege|state secrets]], although the judges said that "In light of extensive government disclosures, the government is hard-pressed to sustain its claim that the very subject matter of the litigation is a state secret."<ref>{{cite web|title=For Publication United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|date=November 16, 2007|publisher=United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|url=http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2007/11/15/0636083.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Eric|last=Lichtblau|title=Court Bars Secret Papers in Eavesdropping Case|date=November 17, 2007|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/17/washington/17nsa.html?pagewanted=print}}</ref>
In a question-and-answer session published on August 22, [[Director of National Intelligence]] [[John Michael McConnell|Mike McConnell]] first confirmed that the private sector had helped the program. McConnell argued that the companies deserved immunity for their help: "Now if you play out the suits at the value they're claimed, it would bankrupt these companies."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_6685679 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120731104224/http://www.elpasotimes.com/ci_6685679 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 31, 2012 |first=Chris |last=Roberts |title=Transcript: Debate on the foreign intelligence surveillance act |date=August 22, 2007 |work=El Paso Times }}</ref> Plaintiffs in the AT&T suit subsequently moved to have McConnell's acknowledgement admitted as evidence.<ref>{{cite news|first=Ellen|last=Nakashima|title=AT&T Plaintiffs Cite McConnell Remarks|series=Admission of Telecom Firms' Involvement in Warrantless Wiretaps Sought as Evidence|date=September 1, 2007|work=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/31/AR2007083101873_pf.html}}</ref>
{{Update section|date=March 2018}}
In a related legal development, on October 13, 2007, [[Joseph P. Nacchio]], the former CEO of [[Qwest Communications]], appealed an April 2007 insider trading conviction by alleging that the government withdrew opportunities for contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars after Qwest refused to participate in an unidentified NSA program that the company thought might be illegal. He claimed that the NSA approached Qwest about participating in a warrantless surveillance program more than six months before 9/11. Nacchio used the allegation to show why his stock sale was not improper.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Ellen Nakashima |author2=Dan Eggen |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Former CEO Says U.S. Punished Phone Firm|series=Qwest Feared NSA Plan Was Illegal, Filing Says|date=October 13, 2007|work=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/12/AR2007101202485_pf.html}}</ref> According to a lawsuit filed against other telecommunications companies for violating customer privacy, AT&T began preparing facilities for the NSA to monitor "phone call information and Internet traffic" seven months before 9/11.<ref name="NYTimes2007-10-14">{{cite news |first=Scott |last=Shane |title=Former Phone Chief Says Spy Agency Sought Surveillance Help Before 9/11 |date=October 14, 2007 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/14/business/14qwest.html?ref=todayspaper |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=October 14, 2007}}</ref>
On January 20, 2006, cosponsors Senator [[Patrick Leahy]] and [[Ted Kennedy]] introduced Senate Resolution 350, a resolution "expressing the sense of the Senate that Senate Joint Resolution 23 (107th Congress), as adopted by the Senate on September 14, 2001, and subsequently enacted as the Authorization for Use of Military Force does not authorize warrantless domestic surveillance of United States citizens".<ref name="Senate.gov-Authorization">{{cite web|url=http://leahy.senate.gov/press/200601/UpdatedAUMF%20Resolution%201-19.pdf|title=Proposed Resolution|work=Authorization for Use of Military Force (Public Law 107-40) does not authorize warrantless domestic surveillance of United States citizens|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060126214740/http://leahy.senate.gov/press/200601/UpdatedAUMF+Resolution+1-19.pdf|archivedate=January 26, 2006|accessdate=January 20, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Senate.gov-Leahy">{{cite press release|title=Leahy on Friday Introduces Resolution Underscoring That Congress Did Not Authorize Illegal Spying on Americans|date=January 20, 2006|publisher=U.S. Senator Patrick Leahy|url=http://leahy.senate.gov/press/200601/012006.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060125203726/http://leahy.senate.gov/press/200601/012006.html|archivedate=January 25, 2006|df=mdy-all}}</ref> This non-binding resolution died without debate.<ref name="Leahy350isdead">{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:s.res.00350:|title=S.RES.350 ‚Äì THOMAS (Library of Congress)|publisher=Thomas.loc.gov|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref>
On September 28, 2006, the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] passed the [[Electronic Surveillance Modernization Act]] (H.R. 5825).<ref name="House.gov-FISA-20060929">[http://wilson.house.gov/NewsAction.asp?FormMode=Releases&ID=1309 House Passes Wilson FISA Bill] {{dead link|date=January 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, Press Release, September 29, 2006.</ref> It died in the Senate. Three competing, mutually exclusive, bills‚Äîthe Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 (S.2455), the [[National Security Surveillance Act]] of 2006 (S.2455) and the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Improvement and Enhancement Act of 2006 (S.3001) ‚Äì were referred for debate to the full Senate,<ref name="FAS.org-20060914">[https://fas.org/blog/secrecy/2006/09/conflicting_bills_on_warrantle.html Conflicting Bills on Warrantless Surveillance Advance in Senate], Secrecy News, September 14, 2006</ref> but did not pass. Each of these bills would have broadened the statutory authorization for electronic surveillance, while subjecting it to some restrictions.
=== Termination === On January 17, 2007, Gonzales informed Senate leaders that the program would not be reauthorized.<ref name="nytimes1" /> "Any electronic surveillance that was occurring as part of the Terrorist Surveillance Program will now be conducted subject to the approval of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court," according to his letter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/irp/congress/2007_cr/fisa011707.html|title=Congressional Record: January 17, 2007, Congressional Record: January 17, 2007|publisher=Federation of American Scientists|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref>
=== Further legal action === The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) sued NSA over the program. Detroit District Court judge [[Anna Diggs Taylor]] ruled on August 17, 2006 that the program was illegal under FISA as well as unconstitutional under the [[First Amendment of the United States Constitution|First]] and [[Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution|Fourth]] amendments of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fl1.findlaw.com/news.findlaw.com/nytimes/docs/nsa/aclunsa81706opn.pdf|title=Findlaw: PDF archive of judicial ruling|format=PDF|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Wired.com-Judge-NSA">{{cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/news/politics/0,71610-0.html?tw=wn_index_3|title=Wired News: Judge Halts NSA Snooping|author=Ryan Singel|date=August 17, 2006|work=Wired|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/18/washington/18nsa.html|title=Judge Finds Wiretap Actions Violate the Law|last1=Liptak|first1=Adam|last2=Lichtblau|first2=Eric|date=August 18, 2006|publisher=|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref> [[Judicial Watch]], a watchdog group, discovered that at the time of the ruling Taylor "serves as a secretary and trustee for a foundation that donated funds to the ACLU of Michigan, a plaintiff in the case".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.judicialwatch.org/printer_5862.shtml|title=US District Judge Who Presided Over Government Wiretapping Case May Have Had Conflict of Interest|date=August 21, 2006|publisher=Judicial Watch|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327032011/http://www.judicialwatch.org/printer_5862.shtml|archivedate=March 27, 2008|deadurl=yes|accessdate=February 20, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
''[[ACLU v. === Proposed FISA amendments === Several commentators raised the issue of whether FISA needed to be amended to address foreign intelligence needs, technology developments and advanced technical intelligence gathering. The intent was to provide programmatic approvals of surveillance of foreign terrorist communications, so that they could then legally be used as evidence for FISA warrants. ''Fixing Surveillance'';<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heritage.org/Press/Commentary/ed012706a.cfm|title=Fixing surveillance|last=K.A. Taipale|first=James Jay Carafano|date=January 25, 2006|work=The Washington Times|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061202001709/http://www.heritage.org/Press/Commentary/ed012706a.cfm|archivedate=December 2, 2006|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''Why We Listen'',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/30/opinion/30bobbitt.html|title=Why We Listen|last=Bobbitt|first=Phillip|date=January 30, 2006|work=The New York Times}}</ref> ''The Eavesdropping Debate We Should be Having'';<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bcsia.ksg.harvard.edu/publication.cfm?program=CORE&ctype=article&item_id=1373|title=The Eavesdropping Debate We Should be Having|last=Bryan Cunnigham|first=Daniel B. L. & Security, No. 8|ssrn=889120}}</ref> address FISA's inadequacies in the post-9/11 context.
The Bush administration contended that amendment was unnecessary because they claimed that the President had inherent authority to approve the NSA program, and that the process of amending FISA might require disclosure of classified information that could harm national security.<ref name="WHbrief121905" /> In response, Senator Leahy said, "If you do not even attempt to persuade Congress to amend the law, you must abide by the law as written."<ref>{{cite press release|title=Statement of The Honorable Patrick Leahy|date=February 6, 2006|publisher=U.S. Senate Committee on the Judiciary|url=http://judiciary.senate.gov/member_statement.cfm?id=1727&wit_id=2629}}</ref> President Bush claimed that the law did not apply because the Constitution gave him "inherent authority" to act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/privacy/spying/23279res20051229.html|title=NSA Spying on Americans Is Illegal | American Civil Liberties Union|date=December 29, 2005|publisher=Aclu.org|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2006/01/print/20060122.html|title=Democrats Continue to Attack Terrorist Surveillance Program|date=November 29, 2012|publisher=Georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref>
Some politicians and commentators used "difficult, if not impossible" to argue that the administration believed Congress would have rejected an amendment. In his written "Responses to Questions from Senator Specter" in which Specter specifically asked why the administration had not sought to amend FISA,<ref>[http://childedlaw.org/publiclaw/pdf/gonzalesanswers.pdf "Responses to Questions from Senator Specter"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061102113024/http://childedlaw.org/publiclaw/pdf/gonzalesanswers.pdf|date=November 2, 2006}}, February 2005.</ref> Gonzales wrote:
{{quote|[W]e were advised by members of Congress that it would be difficult, if not impossible to pass such legislation without revealing the nature of the program and the nature of certain intelligence capabilities. That disclosure would likely have harmed our national security, and that was an unacceptable risk we were not prepared to take.}}
Competing legislative proposals to authorize the NSA program subject to Congressional or FISC oversight were the subject of Congressional hearings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/irp/congress/2006_hr/index.html#fisa4|title=FIS linking to 2006 FISA Congressional Hearings material|publisher=Fas.org|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref> On March 16, 2006, Senators Mike DeWine, Lindsey Graham, Chuck Hagel and Olympia Snowe introduced the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 (S.2455),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/irp/congress/2006_cr/dewine031606.html|title=Press Release of Senator DeWine|publisher=Fas.org|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdt.org/security/20060324dewinebill.pdf|title=Dewine Bill as introduced|format=PDF|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref> that gave the President limited statutory authority to conduct electronic surveillance of suspected terrorists in the US, subject to enhanced Congressional oversight. That day Specter introduced the National Security Surveillance Act of 2006 (S.2453),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://information-retrieval.info/docs/SpecterFloorStmt.pdf|title=Specter Floor Statement|format=PDF|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://information-retrieval.info/docs/NSAfinal.pdf|title=Specter Bill as introduced|format=PDF|accessdate=February 23, 2013}}</ref> which would amend FISA to grant retroactive amnesty<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/06/08/AR2006060801992.html "Specter Offers Compromise on NSA Surveillance"], ''The Washington Post'', June 9, 2006</ref> for warrantless surveillance conducted under presidential authority and provide FISC jurisdiction to review, authorize and oversee "electronic surveillance programs". On May 24, 2006, Specter and Feinstein introduced the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Improvement and Enhancement Act of 2006 (S.3001) denoting FISA as the exclusive means to conduct foreign intelligence surveillance.
On September 13, 2006, the Senate Judiciary Committee voted to approve all three, mutually exclusive bills, thus, leaving it to the full Senate to resolve.<ref name="FAS.org-20060914" />
On July 18, 2006, U.S. Representative Heather Wilson introduced the Electronic Surveillance Modernization Act (H.R. 5825). Wilson's bill would give the President the authority to authorize electronic surveillance of international phone calls and e-mail linked specifically to identified terrorist groups immediately following or in anticipation of an armed or terrorist attack. Surveillance beyond the initially authorized period would require a FISA warrant or a presidential certification to Congress. On September 28, 2006 the House of Representatives passed Wilson's bill and it was referred to the Senate.<ref name="House.gov-FISA-20060929" />
Each of these bills would in some form broaden the statutory authorization for electronic surveillance, while still subjecting it to some restrictions. The Specter-Feinstein bill would extend the peacetime period for obtaining retroactive warrants to seven days and implement other changes to facilitate eavesdropping while maintaining FISC oversight. The DeWine bill, the Specter bill, and the Electronic Surveillance Modernization Act (already passed by the House) would all authorize some limited forms or periods of warrantless electronic surveillance subject to additional programmatic oversight by either the FISC (Specter bill) or Congress (DeWine and Wilson bills).
